awd_titl_txt: NRT-DESE:  Graduate Training in Data-Enabled Research into Human Behavior and its Cognitive and Neural Mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the cognitive and neural basis of human behavior is one of the most fundamental areas of scientific inquiry for the 21st Century. It will impact almost every facet of human existence, including commerce, education, health care, and national security, as well as basic science. This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award prepares Ph.D. students at the University of Rochester to advance discoveries at the intersection of computer science, brain and cognitive sciences, and neuroscience. Trainees will be prepared to harness the burgeoning power of data science to make novel inroads into understanding the neural foundations of human behavior.  Trainees will learn to be equally comfortable applying these skills in industrial and academic settings.  By emphasizing both practical applications and basic science, this program will prepare trainees to develop research solutions relevant to today?s societal needs as well as develop research approaches of critical importance to future needs.

Focusing on understanding the nature of intelligence, this program will provide students with skills to blend expertise in data science and computer science with a deep understanding of experimental approaches to collecting and analyzing neural and behavioral data. The program will use theories and methods from data science including machine learning and statistics to provide students with a foundation for theory development, computational modeling, and data analysis. This foundation will serve as a conceptual and methodological framework unifying their studies of artificial and biological intelligence. The hands-on, project-oriented nature of this program will provide students with the capabilities needed to conceptualize, design, and implement large-scale research projects from beginning to end. This traineeship provides a novel model for structuring interdisciplinary education, based on a modular cross-training course followed by an interdisciplinary practicum course, which can be replicated in many fields and universities.

por.por_cntn:
In this report, we describe the notable outcomes in research, student training, and summarize the results from participant and faculty-mentor evaluations.

Research: This NRT grant has supported a broad range of cutting-edge research at the interface of cognitive science and data science. Over the course of the project, these research efforts have involved 16 faculty members and their laboratories.  These efforts have been broad in scope but the majority of projects have fallen into the following major themes:

            Natural language processing: examples of this include generating algorithms and learning schemas for machine translation control of humanoid robots, and semantic parsing

            Human and machine learning: examples of these efforts include studies of how working memory is adapted to the statistics of the environment, and how machine learning can be used to interpret human neuroimaging data and decode mental states.

            Advanced analysis of neurophysiological data: efforts in this area have included using machine learning to develop probabilistic models for how the brain performs perceptual inference, and developing hierarchical Bayesian models of how populations of neurons can perform causal inference.

            Artificial intelligence for human-computer interaction: examples of major efforts in this area include developing algorithms for the analysis of body language and other non-verbal aspects of communication, and techniques that can assess the trustworthiness of individuals in social networks by analyzing behavioral patterns.

Student training: In five years, we have supported 51 PhD students in Computer Science and Brain and Cognitive Sciences. 37% of the students were from underrepresented minorities. Students who have graduated have won tenure track positions at R1 institutions, including postdoctoral opportunities at Harvard and Penn as well as full time employment opportunities in Google. Students who are currently enrolled have received fellowships from the US defense and internal fellowships within the university for excellence in teaching and academics. The students benefited from having the opportunity to closely interact with influential external speakers from academia as well as industry. The speakers included Rick Rashid (founder of Microsoft Research), Bill Feaster (a thought leader in health) as well as prominent academics like Jon Kleinberg and Sandy Pentland.  

Another outcome of the NSF NRT graduate training program is a notable increase in the number of graduate students pursuing joint Ph.D. degrees. Of the trainees (i.e., students who completed the courses ?Methods in Data- Enabled Research into Human Behavior and its Cognitive and Neural Mechanisms" and "Practicum in Data-Enabled Research into Human Behavior and its Cognitive and Neural Mechanisms"), two students received joint Ph.D. degrees bridging the Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences and the Department of Computer Science, and an additional six students are currently pursuing joint Ph.D. degrees bridging these two departments.  We regard this as a strong indication that our NRT training program stimulated interdisciplinary interests in our students, and provided them with the training and research opportunities to pursue these interests.

Evaluation summary: The evaluation instruments, including a student focus group, student surveys (pre-/post-) and an end of program faculty survey, provided rich information about student outcomes for the program. As an overarching outcome of the program, students spoke about how their interdisciplinary experience offered them unique exposure to a complementary field and individuals outside of their area. In each year of the NSF NRT, students made gains in key areas targeted by the program including confidence and knowledge of academic content. Moreover, most students indicated that they were motivated to gain additional knowledge. In addition to reinforcing interdisciplinary knowledge, students found collaborative projects to prepare themselves for future professional activities. In the later years of the grant, communication workshops were mentioned by students as a favorite offering and key to achieving their professional goals. Student participation in a national conference was also a highlight amongst the grant activities. In addition to providing technical training and professional experience, students enhanced their collegiality through attending a conference as a cohort.

 


Last Modified: 12/04/2021
Modified by: Ajay Anand
